Then the Demon King, holding a strong bow in his hand and five arrows,
together with his male and female relatives, went to the foot of the PÄpÄtalagiri tree.
He saw the sage, still and unmoving, wishing to cross the sea of the three realms of existence.
At that time, the Demon King held a bow in his left hand, drew an arrow with his right hand, and said to the Bodhisattva:
'You are of the ká¹£atriya caste, death is very frightening, why don't you quickly get up?

You should practice the duties of a wheel-turning king, abandon the path of renunciation, engage in giving, and attain the bliss of rebirth in the heavens. This path is the most supreme and superior to your previous practices;
You are of the caste of wheel-turning kings, yet you beg for alms. This is not appropriate.
If you do not rise now, just sit comfortably and do not abandon your original vow.

I will test your shooting skills. With one shot from my sharp arrow, even ascetic sages will be frightened upon hearing the sound of my arrow, let alone you, Gautama, who will be able to endure this poison?
If you quickly rise, you may attain safety.'
When Mara said these words to frighten the Bodhisattva, the Bodhisattva remained calm, unstartled, and unmoved;
Mara then drew his bow and shot an arrow, along with the celestial maidens.
At that time, the Bodhisattva did not look at the arrow. The arrow stopped in mid-air, with its tip pointing downward, transforming into a lotus flower.
Then the three celestial maidens said to the Bodhisattva:
'You are a virtuous one, respected by gods and humans, you should have attendants to serve you;
We are now in our prime years, and our heavenly maidens are more beautiful than you.
The gods have now sent us to serve you, we will attend you day and night, sleeping and waking by your side.'
The Bodhisattva replied:

'You have planted little goodness and obtained a heavenly body, but you do not think of impermanence and act with deceit. Although your form is beautiful, your mind is not upright. Lustful and unwholesome, after death you will certainly fall into the three evil paths and receive the body of a bird or beast, and it will be very difficult to escape;
You now want to disturb my concentration, with impure thoughts. You may leave now, I have no need of you.'

At that time, the three heavenly maidens transformed into old women, with white hair, wrinkled faces, lost teeth, drooling, sunken flesh, protruding bones, and a belly as big as a drum, leaning on a cane, unable to walk properly.
When the demon king saw this firmness, he thought to himself:
In the past, when I shot Mahesvara in the snowy mountains, he became frightened and lost his good mind;
But now I cannot move Gautama. Since neither this arrow nor my three daughters can make him feel love or hatred,
I must devise another plan.
He then used soft words to entice the Bodhisattva, saying:
If you are not happy receiving pleasure in the human realm, you can now ascend to the heavenly palace;
I will give up my heavenly position and the five sense pleasures, and give them all to you.
The Bodhisattva replied:
You cultivated a little giving in a past life, and now you have become the king of the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others;
This merit has an end. You will have to return to the lower realms and sink in the three evil paths. It will be very difficult to escape.
This is a cause for sin, and I do not need it.
The demon said to the Bodhisattva:
'You know the fruits of my retribution,
but who knows the fruits of your retribution?'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'Only this earth knows the fruits of my retribution.'
After saying this, the great earth trembled in six ways;
Then the earth spirit emerged from the ground, holding a seven-jeweled vase filled with lotus flowers, and said to Mara:
'In the past, the Bodhisattva gave away his head, eyes, marrow, brain, and even his blood soaked the great earth;
He gave away his kingdom, city, wife, children, elephants, horses, and precious treasures, beyond measure;
He sought the unsurpassed true path, and for this reason, you should not disturb the Bodhisattva now.'
Having heard this, Mara became frightened and his hair stood on end;
Then the earth spirit bowed at the Bodhisattva's feet, made offerings with flowers, and suddenly disappeared.
At that time, the Demon King thought to himself:
I used a strong bow, sharp arrows, and my three daughters, as well as skillful means and kind words to entice him, but I could not disturb the mind of this Gautama.
Now I shall devise even more kinds of skillful means, gather a vast army, and use force to intimidate him.

As soon as he had this thought, his troops suddenly arrived, filling the sky, with various appearances, some holding spears and swords, some with their heads wearing large trees, some holding golden clubs, with all kinds of weapons fully equipped;
some with the heads of pigs, fish, donkeys, horses, lions, dragons, bears, tigers, and other beasts;
some with one body and many heads;
some with one eye in each face;
some with many eyes;
some with large bellies and long bodies;
some emaciated with no bellies;ğŸ”½some with long legs and large knees;
some with large feet and fat calves;
some with long claws and sharp fangs;
some with their heads in front of their chests;
Some had two feet, some had many bodies;
Some had large faces, some had faces on the sides;
Some had the color of ash and soil;
Some emitted smoke and flames from their bodies;
Some had the body of an elephant carrying a mountain;
Some had disheveled hair and were naked;
Some had half their faces red and half white;
Some had lips hanging down to the ground;
Some had their upper garments pulled up;ğŸ”½Some had tiger skins on their faces;
Some had lion and snake skins;
Some had snakes all around their bodies;
Some had fire burning on their heads;
Some glared with eyes bulging out of their sockets;
Some walked sideways, jumping and leaping;
Some spun around in the air;
Some ran and roared in fright;
There were such evil creatures in countless forms surrounding the Bodhisattva.
Some wanted to tear apart the Bodhisattva's body;
Some had smoke rising in the four directions, flames shooting up to the sky, or mad sounds erupting, shaking the mountains and valleys, with wind, fire, smoke, and dust obscuring the view;
The waters of the four great oceans all boiled at once.
The Dharma-protecting gods, humans, dragons, ghosts, and others all became angry at the demon hordes, their anger and rage increasing, blood flowing from their pores.
The pure-dwelling celestial hosts, seeing this evil demon harassing the Bodhisattva;
with a compassionate heart, they felt pity for him;
and so they came down, filling the sky to the side.
Seeing the demon armies, countless and boundless, surrounding the Bodhisattva, making great evil sounds, shaking heaven and earth;
the Bodhisattva's mind was in concentration, his face without any different expression, like a lion among a herd of deer.
They all exclaimed:
'Alas, how strange!
Never before has there been such a thing. The Bodhisattva is determined to attain perfect enlightenment.'
These demon hordes urged each other on, each using their full power to crush the Bodhisattva;
some glared with bared fangs;
some flew around wildly and threw things;
the Bodhisattva watched them as if they were children playing;
the demons became even more distressed and enraged, increasing their fighting strength even more.
Because of the power of the bodhisattva's compassion, those who held rocks were unable to lift them;
those who could lift them were unable to put them down;
flying knives and dancing swords stopped in midair;
lightning, thunder, and rain turned into five-colored flowers;
the poisonous breath of evil dragons transformed into fragrant breezes;
the forms of various evil beings, wishing to harm the bodhisattva, were unable to move.
The demon had a sister named MigÄ and another named Kali, each holding a skull cup in their hands, making various strange appearances in front of the bodhisattva, disturbing the bodhisattva.
These demon hordes, with various ugly forms, wishing to frighten the bodhisattva, were ultimately unable to move a single hair on the bodhisattva's body. The demon became even more sorrowful.
There was a spirit in the sky named BhadrapÄla who, hiding his body, said:
I now see the Venerable Sage, my mind and thoughts are at ease, without any thoughts of resentment;
These demon hordes give rise to poisonous thoughts, and in places without enmity, they give rise to anger.
This foolish and evil demon only tires himself in vain, and will never obtain anything.
Today you should abandon thoughts of anger and harm. You may be able to blow Mount Sumeru with your mouth and cause it to collapse;
fire can be made cold;
water can be made hot;
the hard nature of earth can be made soft;

but you cannot destroy the good fruits cultivated by the Bodhisattva over many eons, the right thoughts and concentration, diligent skillful means, and the light of pure wisdom. These four virtues cannot be cut off;
you cannot create obstacles for him and prevent him from attaining perfect enlightenment, just as a thousand suns shining can surely dispel darkness;
digging the ground can obtain water. With diligent skillful means, there is nothing that cannot be obtained.
Sentient beings in the world are mired in the three poisons, without anyone to save them. The Bodhisattva, with compassion, seeks the medicine of wisdom to remove the afflictions of the world.
How can you now disturb and agitate them?
Sentient beings in the world are deluded and ignorant, all attached to wrong views;
Now establishing the eye of the Dharma, cultivating the right path, wishing to guide sentient beings.
How can you now disturb and agitate the guide?
This is unacceptable.
It is like being in the wilderness, wishing to deceive the merchant guide.
Sentient beings have fallen into the great darkness, confused and not knowing where to stop, the bodhisattva lights the great lamp of wisdom.
How can you now wish to blow it out?
Sentient beings are now drowning in the sea of birth and death, the bodhisattva cultivates the great ship of wisdom.
How can you now wish to cause them to sink?
Patience is the bud, firmness is the root, the unsurpassed great Dharma is the great fruit.
How can you now wish to attack it?
The fetters of greed, anger, and delusion bind sentient beings, the bodhisattva practices austerities, wishing to untie them;
Today, I will definitely sit cross-legged under this tree and attain supreme enlightenment.
This ground is the adamantine seat of the buddhas of the past;
Other places may shift, but this spot is immovable. It can bear wondrous concentration, and cannot be destroyed by you.
You should now give rise to a mind of joy and cease your arrogant thoughts. Cultivate the notion of knowing and serving [the Buddha].

At that time, when the demon king heard the voice in the sky and saw that the Bodhisattva remained calm and unchanged, the demon's heart was ashamed and he abandoned his arrogance. He then returned by the way he came to the heavenly palace.
The demons were worried and dejected, all fleeing and scattering. Their thoughts were discouraged and they lost their power and might. The various weapons of war were scattered in the forest.
When the evil demons retreated and scattered, the Bodhisattva's mind was pure and still, unmoving.
The sky was free from smoke and mist, and the wind did not stir the branches.
The setting sun stopped its light and became even brighter.
The clear moon shines through, the myriad stars are brilliant;
The hidden darkness is no longer obstructed;
The devas in the sky rain down wonderful flowers and incense, and make various kinds of music, making offerings to the Bodhisattva.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, with the power of compassion, on the night of the seventh day of the second month, after subduing Mara, emitted a great light;
He then entered concentration and contemplated the truth, being self-mastered in meditation on the various dharmas;

He knew all the good and evil deeds created in the past, from this birth to that, his parents, relatives, poverty and wealth, nobility and humbleness, longevity and shortness of life, and even their names and surnames, all clearly; he then gave rise to a great compassionate mind towards sentient beings.
He thought to himself:
'All sentient beings have no one to save them. They revolve in the five paths and do not know how to escape. They are all false and have no truth;
Yet within this, they give rise to suffering and joy.
Having had this thought, he reached the end of the first watch of the night.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having reached the middle of the night, attained the heavenly eye;
He observed the world and saw everything clearly, like seeing one's own face in a clear mirror.
He saw that sentient beings have innumerable kinds, dying here and being born there, following their good and evil actions, receiving the retribution of suffering and happiness.
He saw that in the hells, sentient beings are tortured, with molten copper poured into their mouths;
Some embrace copper pillars;
Some lie on iron beds;ğŸ”½Some are boiled in iron cauldrons;
Some are roasted on spits over fires;
Some are eaten by tigers, wolves, hawks, and dogs;
Some avoid the fires and rely on the shade of trees, but the tree leaves fall, turning into swords and knives that cut their bodies;
Some are sawed and cut with axes and saws;ğŸ”½Some are thrown into boiling ash rivers;
Some are thrown into cesspools;
They experience such various kinds of suffering, and due to the retribution of their karma, they die but do not perish.
When the Bodhisattva saw such things, he contemplated in his mind:
'These sentient beings, in the past, created evil karma for the sake of worldly pleasures, and now they experience extremely great suffering as a result.
If people see such evil retribution, they should never again give rise to unwholesome thoughts.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva further observed that animals, according to their various actions, receive mixed and ugly forms;
Some are killed for their bones, flesh, sinews, horns, skin, tusks, feathers and fur;
Some are made by people to carry heavy loads, exhausted by hunger and thirst, and no one is aware of them;
Some have their noses pierced;
Some have their heads hooked;
Always using their flesh to provide for people, they return to their own kind and devour each other;
They experience such various kinds of suffering.
The Bodhisattva, upon seeing this, gave rise to a mind of great compassion and contemplated to himself:

These sentient beings always use their physical strength to serve others, and they are subjected to beatings, hunger, and thirst. This is all the karmic retribution for their past cultivation of evil deeds.
At that time, the Bodhisattva next contemplated the hungry ghosts;
He saw that they always dwell in darkness, never having seen the light of the sun and moon for even a moment;
They are of the same kind and do not see each other;
Their bodies are huge, with bellies like Mount Tai, and throats as thin as needles, with a great fire constantly burning in their mouths;
They are always tormented by hunger and thirst, and for thousands of millions of years, they do not hear the word food;
Even if heavenly rain falls upon them, it turns into fire-beads;
Sometimes, if they happen to approach a river, ocean, or pond, the water immediately transforms into boiling copper and charred embers;
When they move or lift a step, the sound is like that of five hundred carts being pulled, and every joint of their limbs is ablaze with fire.
The Bodhisattva, seeing them undergo such various sufferings, gives rise to a mind of great compassion and thinks to himself:
All of this is due to their past stinginess and greed, accumulating wealth without giving in charity, causing them to now undergo this retribution of suffering.
If people see them undergoing this pain, they should be generous and not be stingy.
Even if they have no wealth, they should still cut their flesh to give in charity.

At that time, the Bodhisattva next observed people, seeing them about to enter the womb from the intermediate state, with their parents coming together, giving rise to a mind of love with inverted thoughts;
immediately taking their impure bodies as their own;
after entering the womb, being between the two intestines, the body being scorched like the suffering of hell;
reaching the full tenth month, they are then born;
when first born, they are held by outsiders, the rough and painful touch like being cut by a sword;
In this way, before long, they return to old age and death, become infants again, and revolve in the five destinies, unable to awaken on their own.
The Bodhisattva, seeing this, gave rise to a mind of great compassion and thought to himself:
All sentient beings have such afflictions. How can they indulge in the five desires in this, mistakenly considering them to be happiness, and yet be unable to cut off the root of delusion?

At that time, the Bodhisattva next contemplated the gods and saw those celestial sons, whose bodies were pure, untainted by dust or defilement, like genuine lapis lazuli, with great radiance, their eyes never blinking;ğŸ”½Some resided on the peak of Mount Sumeru;
Some resided in the four corners of Mount Sumeru;
Some resided in the midst of empty space;
Their minds were always joyful, with nothing disagreeable. They played heavenly beautiful music to entertain themselves, not knowing day or night;
In all the directions, there was nothing but the most exquisite;
Gazing to the east, they became engrossed, forgetting to turn for years;
The Westerners indulged in pleasures, not returning for years;
Even in the north and south, it was all like this;
Food and clothing arrived as soon as they were thought of.
Although there were such pleasing things, they were still scorched by the fire of desire. Moreover, they saw when the blessings of those devas were exhausted, the five signs of death appeared:
First, the flowers on their heads withered;
Second, their eyes blinked;
Third, the light on their bodies disappeared;
Fourth, sweat came out from their armpits;
Fifth, they naturally left their original seats.
The various retinues, seeing the five signs of death appear on the bodies of the devas, felt longing in their hearts;
The devas also saw their own bodies have the five signs of death;
And they saw the retinues longing for them. At that time, they gave rise to great suffering.
The Bodhisattva, having seen that those devas had such things, gave rise to a mind of great compassion and thought to himself:

'These heavenly beings, having originally cultivated a little goodness, have attained the pleasures of the heavens, but as their karmic rewards are about to be exhausted, they give rise to great suffering;
Having passed away, they abandon their heavenly bodies, and some fall into the three evil destinies;
Having originally created good actions, they seek after pleasant karmic rewards;
But what they now attain is little pleasure and much suffering, like a starving person eating food mixed with poison. Although it is delicious at first, in the end it becomes a great calamity.
How can the wise be greedy for and enjoy this?
The gods of the form and formless realms, seeing their long lifespans, consider them to be permanent and blissful;
But when they see them change and decay, they give rise to great suffering and immediately give rise to wrong views, denying cause and effect;
Because of this, they revolve in the three paths and experience all kinds of suffering.'
The Bodhisattva, with the power of his heavenly eye, observed the five destinies and gave rise to a mind of great compassion, thinking to himself:
'In the three realms, there is not a single joy.
Thinking like this, he reached the end of the middle night.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, in the third night, contemplated the nature of sentient beings, 'By what causes and conditions does old age and death exist?'
He immediately knew that old age and death are based on birth. If one is apart from birth, then there is no old age and death;
Moreover, this birth does not come from the heavens, nor does it come from oneself;
It is not born without conditions, but is born from causes and conditions;
It is born from the karma of the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.
Moreover, he contemplated, 'From what does the karma of the three realms arise?'
He immediately knew that the karma of the three realms arises from the four kinds of grasping.
Moreover, he contemplated, 'From what does the four kinds of grasping arise?'
He immediately knew that the four kinds of grasping arise from craving.
Moreover, he contemplated, 'From what does craving arise?'
He then knew that craving arises from feeling.
Moreover, he contemplated, 'From what does feeling arise?'
He then knew that feeling arises from contact.
Moreover, he contemplated, 'From what does contact arise?'
He then knew that contact arises from the six sense bases.
He further contemplated, Where do the six sense bases arise from?
He then knew that the six sense bases arise from name-and-form.
He further contemplated, Where does name-and-form arise from?
He then knew that name-and-form arises from consciousness.
He further contemplated, Where does consciousness arise from?
He then knew that consciousness arises from karmic formations.
He further contemplated, Where do karmic formations arise from?
He then knew that karmic formations arise from ignorance.ğŸ”½If ignorance ceases, then karmic formations cease;
If karmic formations cease, then consciousness ceases;
If consciousness ceases, then name-and-form ceases;
If name-and-form ceases, then the six sense bases cease;
If the six sense bases cease, then contact ceases;ğŸ”½If contact ceases, then feeling ceases;
If feeling ceases, then craving ceases;ğŸ”½If craving ceases, then grasping ceases;
If grasping ceases, then becoming ceases;
If becoming ceases, then birth ceases;
If birth ceases, then old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress cease.
In this way, contemplating the twelve links of dependent origination in reverse and forward order, in the third watch of the night, he broke through ignorance;
When the light of dawn appears, one attains the light of wisdom, cuts off the hindrances of habits, and accomplishes omniscience.
At that time, the TathÄgata thought to himself:
The eightfold noble path is what the buddhas of the three times have practiced, the road leading to parinirvÄá¹‡a;
I have now tread it, my wisdom is penetrating, and there are no obstructions.

At that time, the great earth shook in eighteen ways, the floating clouds and flying dust all became still and pure, the heavenly drum sounded spontaneously with a wonderful sound, a fragrant breeze gently arose, soft, cool and refreshing, multicolored auspicious clouds rained down sweet dew, and the flowers and fruits in the garden bloomed out of season.
It also rained mandÄra flowers, great mandÄra flowers, maÃ±jÅ«á¹£aka flowers, great maÃ±jÅ«á¹£aka flowers, golden flowers, silver flowers, and vaiá¸Å«rya flowers;
Seven-jeweled lotuses surrounded the bodhi tree, filling thirty-six yojanas.
At that time, the devas made celestial music, scattered flowers, burned incense, sang praises, held celestial jeweled canopies and banners, filling the sky to make offerings to the TathÄgata.
The offerings set up by the eight groups of dragons and spirits were also like this.
At that time, all sentient beings were all loving and kind, without thoughts of anger or harm.

They rejoiced and leaped for joy, as if seeing holy traces, without feelings of fear, their minds were disciplined and gentle, free from thoughts of arrogance and conceit, and also without thoughts of stinginess, jealousy, flattery, or deception.
The devas of the five pure abodes, who were free from the faculties of joy and pleasure, were also all delighted and could not contain themselves.
The suffering and pain of the hells temporarily ceased, and they gave rise to great joy.
All the animals that ate each other no longer had evil thoughts.
The hungry ghosts were satisfied and had no thoughts of hunger or thirst.
In the dark places of the world that were not illuminated by the majestic light of the sun and moon, there was great brightness.
The sentient beings in the ten directions all saw each other and said:
How is it that there are suddenly sentient beings here?
Because the Great Sage, the Dharma King, appeared in the world, using the great light of the Dharma to destroy the darkness of non-Dharma, causing everything to become bright and clear.
The former kings of the sugarcane clan, who renounced the country to study the Way and attained the five supernatural powers,

and those who attained rebirth in the heavens by practicing the ten wholesome deeds, all used their spiritual powers to come to the Bodhi tree, hovering in the sky, joyfully joining their palms and praising, saying:
Within our sugarcane clan, you are able to sever all defilements, attain omniscience, and become the eye of the world. It is truly extraordinary.
Everyone was overjoyed, but only the Demon King was worried in his heart.
At that time, the TathÄgata single-mindedly contemplated for seven days, gazing at the king of trees, thinking to himself:
'I have exhausted all defilements in this place, and what was to be done has been accomplished, and my original vow has been fulfilled.
The Dharma I have attained is profound and difficult to understand, and only the Buddhas can know it.
All sentient beings in the five turbidities are obscured by greed, anger, ignorance, wrong views, arrogance, and flattery;
They have little merit and dull faculties, and lack wisdom. How can they understand the Dharma I have attained?
If I now turn the wheel of the Dharma for them, they will certainly be confused and unable to believe and accept it, but will slander it and fall into evil paths to experience various sufferings.
I would rather remain silent and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.'
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke in verse, saying:
The noble path is extremely difficult to ascend, and the fruit of wisdom is difficult to attain;
I have been able to accomplish all of this difficulty.
The wisdom I have attained is subtle and supreme,
But sentient beings are dull-witted, attached to pleasure and blinded by delusion,
Flowing along with the current of birth and death, unable to reverse its source;
How can I deliver such beings?'

At that time, after the TathÄgata had this thought, the Great Brahma King saw that the TathÄgata had already accomplished the holy fruit but was silently abiding without turning the wheel of the Dharma, and his mind was filled with worry and distress. He immediately thought to himself:

'In the past, for the sake of sentient beings, the World-Honored One had been in birth and death for countless eons. He gave up kingdoms, cities, wives, children, head, eyes, marrow, and brain, enduring various sufferings. Only now has his wish been fulfilled, and he has accomplished supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is he silent and not expounding the Dharma?
For a long time, sentient beings have been drowning in birth and death. I should now go and request him to turn the wheel of the Dharma.'

Having had this thought, he immediately left the heavenly palace, in the time it takes for a strong man to bend and extend his arm, he arrived at the TathÄgata's place, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him a hundred thousand times, then stood to one side, knelt with palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One, in the past, for the sake of sentient beings, you dwelled in birth and death for a long time;
You gave away your body, head, and eyes, and endured various sufferings, extensively cultivating the roots of virtue.
Now that you have attained supreme enlightenment, why are you silent and not expounding the Dharma?
Sentient beings, for a long night, have been drowning in birth and death, falling into the darkness of ignorance, and it is extremely difficult for them to escape.
However, there are sentient beings who, in past lives, have been close to good friends, planted various roots of virtue, and are able to hear the Dharma and receive the holy path.
I only pray that the World-Honored One, for their sake, with the power of great compassion, will turn the wonderful Dharma wheel.
Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, up to the devas of freely partaking of others' emanations, also did the same, requesting the TathÄgata to turn the great Dharma wheel for the sake of all beings.
At that time, the World-Honored One replied to the Great Brahma King and Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, and the others, saying:
I also wish to turn the Dharma wheel for all beings, but the Dharma I have attained is subtle and profound, difficult to understand and know.
Ordinary beings are unable to believe and accept it, and give rise to slanderous thoughts, falling into the hells.
This is why I remain silent.
At that time, the Brahma Kings and the others made their request three times;
At that time, the TathÄgata remained silent for a full seven days, accepting their request.
The Brahma Kings and the others, knowing that the Buddha had accepted their request, bowed their heads to his feet and each returned to their abodes.
At that time, the World-Honored One, having accepted the request of the Brahma Kings and the others,

For another seven days, he used the Buddha eye to observe the upper, middle, and lower faculties of sentient beings, as well as their afflictions, which were also of upper, middle, and lower levels, for a full fourteen days.
At that time, the World-Honored One further contemplated:
I will now open the gate of the sweet dew Dharma. Who should be the first to hear it?
The sage AralÄ« has sharp wisdom and is easy to enlighten. Moreover, he made a vow before, saying, 'When you attain the Way, please save me.'
As he had this thought, a voice in the sky said:
The sage AralÄ« passed away last night.
At that time, the World-Honored One immediately replied to the voice in the sky, saying:
I also know that he passed away last night.
He further contemplated:
The sage KalÄpa has sharp faculties and clear understanding. He should also hear it first.
The voice in the sky again said:
The sage KalÄpa passed away last night.
At that time, the World-Honored One again replied, saying:
'I also know that he died last night.'
At that time, the World-Honored One further thought to himself:

'The five people sent by the royal preceptor and ministers to attend to me, namely Kauá¹‡á¸inya and the others, are all very intelligent, and in past lives they made vows to be the first to hear the Dharma;
I should now first open the Dharma door for these five people.'
He further thought to himself:
'The place where ancient buddhas turned the wheel of the Dharma was always in the Deer Park where sages dwelt in the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, and the dwelling place of these five people is also there;
I should now go to their dwelling place and turn the great wheel of the Dharma.'
Having thought this, he rose from his seat and went to the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«.
At that time, there were five hundred merchants, with two leaders named Bhadrika and BhÄradvÄja, who were passing through a wilderness.
At that time, a celestial spirit said to him:

There is a TathÄgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, a Sugata, an Understander of the World, an Unsurpassed One, a Tamer of Men, a Teacher of Gods and Men, a Buddha, a Bhagavat, who has appeared in the world;
He is the supreme field of merit. You should now be the first to make offerings to him.
When the merchant heard the celestial spirit's words, he replied:
Excellent!
As you have said.
He further asked the celestial spirit:
Where is the World-Honored One now?
The celestial spirit replied:
The World-Honored One will arrive here soon.
Then the TathÄgata, with countless celestial beings leading the way in front and following behind, reached the village of TÄdya.
When the merchant saw the TathÄgata's majestic appearance and adornments, and also saw the celestial beings surrounding him in front and behind, he became even more joyful;
